title: Does fingering really matter in piano if you're playing the right notes? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, it does. There are already a lot of good answers to this question. I’ll start by confessing that I use a lot of lousy fingering, even though I’m a fairly advanced adult player. And I would have been better off developing good habits as a child. There are couple of important things about fingering that really aren’t obvious when you’re a beginner, or even moderately advanced. So it really isn’t clear why fingering is important until much later. (And honestly, I’ve never heard teachers really explain *why* fingering is important in this way.) First, fingerings are about reliability. One important problem in advanced music is being able to play a passage correctly repeatedly. You obviously can’t go into a performance with “well, I hope this hard passage is going to work out right.” Simply knowing that you’re going to finger it the same way every time is a huge help. But even beyond that, in complex passages there are frequently fingerings that aren’t obvious; that are actually more “difficult” than the obvious ones; but are more reliable. You’re less likely to slip or miss. Second (and this may be a restatement of the first): Fingerings are less about the note you’re playing now than the note you’ll be playing next, or after that. Good fingerings set up what you’re going to play in the future. And a little difficulty now might be a good down-payment for having your fingers in the right position a few notes later. This happens a LOT in Bach. You’re often using an odd fingering now to make something possible 5 or 6 notes later. Third: fingering is important for legato and tone control. Some fingerings are easy but thumpy—some finger (usually the thumb) is going to put an accent where you don’t want it, and a good fingering will help to smooth things out. (Sometimes it’s as simple as “Don’t play that note with the thumb!”) Fingerings printed in books aren’t absolute. Well, maybe in beginners’ books… But I’ve seen fingerings in advanced literature that just make no sense—the Paderewski Chopin editions come to mind. My current teacher says that the fingerings in Henle’s Beethoven editions work better for pianists with small hands. So you shouldn’t be afraid to experiment, and find out what works for you. But fingering is not just a matter of playing the right notes… it’s about playing the right notes reliably, and with the right dynamics. And I’ll be the first to say that this is a “do as I say, not as as I do” answer. I wish I had developed better habits as a beginner, but it’s too late for that. Now I have to develop good habits as an adult, and that’s a lot harder.

The highest reason why I believe fingering really does matter, beyond what has already been said, is muscle memory. Not only is it important to choose the most physically correct fingering, but it is important to commit to that fingering once it has been figured out. All physical activities rely upon muscle memory, and every time you play a song with new fingering, you are telling your brain, "forget the pathway you were forging before! make this new one!!" and pretty soon you are stuck with a whole lot of shallow pathways, instead of one epic path that you can always rely on. (I apologize if what I am saying is already abundantly obvious.) The best feeling is when my fingers know a piece so well, I can execute it effortlessly. Only when the fingers have been taught exactly where to be at exactly what moment, can a piece be effortless. If the fingering is inconsistent, even on a single note in the song, how can your fingers know what to expect? My teacher always said they must be rigorously trained, and not confused, like little puppies. ;) So yes, fingering matters, and good, simple consistent fingering matters a whole lot, from the most basic tunes up to the high heavens of musical accomplishment.
